results.abstract: Jack Hitt article on Centennial Challenges, design contests by which NASA is enlisting backyard inventors to brainstorm new technologies for possible return to moon; prize money in seven contests ranges from $200,000 for space glove, won by Peter K Homer, out-of-work director of local community center in Maine, to $2 million for creation of new lunar lander; part of impetus for challenges is fact that Americans, perhaps more so than people of other nations, have great faith in idea of outsider inventor; photos (L)

headline.main: The Amateur Future of Space Travel

results.snippet: How NASA turned to America’s basement brainstormers, workbench concocters and garage tinkerers to revive the space program.
results.lead_paragraph: When Peter K. Homer, an out-of-work director of a local community center in Maine, first heard that NASA was turning to America's backyard inventors to brainstorm new technologies for a possible return to the moon, he had an idea. With NASA sponsoring seven design contests for everything from a new lunar lander to a new space glove, anybody with a home-brewed invention could enter. Homer's previous jobs included some gigs in the aerospace industry as well as work sewing boat sails. So, Homer told me not long ago, he ruled out building a flying spacecraft but decided that ''the glove contest represented something of the scale I could achieve working out of my home by myself.'' He'd always been a garage tinkerer, he said, and being unemployed, he also wanted to prove to his 14-year-old son ''that you can do anything if you put your mind to it.'' Oh, he added offhandedly, ''the money is a motivator, too.'' At stake was a prize -- presented with one of those giant cardboard checks -- for $200,000.

results.abstract: Former astronaut Capt Lisa M Nowak tells police she drove to Orlando from Texas to meet romantic rival Capt Colleen Shipman because she wanted to know where she stood in love triangle; she is accused of attempted kidnapping and other charges (S)

headline.main: Ex-Astronaut Told Why She Met Rival

results.snippet: Capt. Lisa M. Nowak, who is accused of attacking a romantic rival, said she went to Orlando, Fla., because she wanted to know where she stood in the love triangle.
results.lead_paragraph: Capt. Lisa M. Nowak, the former astronaut accused of attacking a romantic rival, told a detective that she had come to Orlando from Texas to meet the woman because she wanted to know where she stood in the love triangle, according to a police interview made public Monday. A 72-page transcript of the interview conducted after Captain Nowak's arrest in February was released by the State Attorney's Office.

results.abstract: Spacewalking astronaut Clayton C Anderson discards camera mounting and ammonia tank weighing more than half ton at International Space Station; outdated equipment is no longer needed and joins more than 9,000 pieces of orbital debris; photo (S)
results.snippet: A spacewalking astronaut, Clayton C. Anderson, discarded a camera mounting and an ammonia tank weighing more than half a ton at the International Space Station.  The outdated equipment was no longer needed and joined more than 9,000 pieces of orbital...
results.lead_paragraph: A spacewalking astronaut, Clayton C. Anderson, discarded a camera mounting and an ammonia tank weighing more than half a ton at the International Space Station. The outdated equipment was no longer needed and joined more than 9,000 pieces of orbital debris already being tracked from Earth. NASA normally tries to avoid adding to the debris, but officials said they felt they had no choice in this case. The equipment had to be removed, and because of a looming 2010 deadline for ending all shuttle flights, the space agency does not have room on its remaining missions to return the tank to Earth.

NASA officials said they were [...]

headline.main: A Bad P.R. Day for NASA

results.snippet: UPDATE (Friday, July 27, 4 p.m.): For those hoping for juicy details on the drunk astronauts, there aren't any. The review panel was told of anecdotes of two astronauts who were intoxicated just prior to flight. However, the panel did not pass on...
results.lead_paragraph: UPDATE (Friday, July 27, 4 p.m.): For those hoping for juicy details on the drunk astronauts, there aren't any. The review panel was told of anecdotes of two astronauts who were intoxicated just prior to flight. However, the panel did not pass on information identifying the individuals or the flights. NASA officials said they were investigating but could not say whether the incidents actually occurred.

results.abstract: NASA investigation shows that astronauts have flown while intoxicated on at least two occasions; astronauts were warned that their drunkenness constituted safety risk; it is unclear whether there is current problem and whether incidents involved space shuttle (M)

headline.main: Astronauts Have Flown While Drunk, NASA Finds

results.snippet: Investigators reported “ ‘heavy use of alcohol’ by astronauts” within 12 hours of flying.

byline.original: By JOHN SCHWARTZ; Kenneth Chang and Warren E. Leary contributed reporting

results.lead_paragraph: NASA's astronauts have flown while intoxicated on at least two occasions, according to reports of an internal NASA investigation, and the astronauts involved were warned that their drunkenness constituted a safety risk to the flight. But it is unclear whether this is a current problem and whether the incidents involved space shuttle flights. The report, which has not been released, was described in an article published yesterday on the Web site of Aviation Week and Space Technology. According to the article, the panel investigators reported '' 'heavy use of alcohol' by astronauts'' within 12 hours of flying.

results.abstract: Once more, NASA is has a lot of explaining to do, this time about a report saying astronauts may have flown while drunk.

headline.main: Woes Enough to Drive NASA to Drink

results.snippet: Once more, NASA is has a lot of explaining to do, this time about a report saying astronauts may have flown while drunk.

results.abstract: NASA is investigating reports that some astronauts may have flown while drunk, and will develop formal code of conduct for astronaut corps; NASA has come under embarrassing scrutiny since allegations were made public in report by magazine Aviation Week & Space Technology; photo (M)

headline.main: NASA Opening an Inquiry Into Drunken-Flying Reports

results.snippet: Officials say they have asked NASA’s safety chief to interview astronauts, flight surgeons and others to determine whether the agency has an alcohol problem.

byline.original: By WARREN E. LEARY; John Schwartz contributed reporting from New York

results.lead_paragraph: NASA is investigating reports that some astronauts may have flown while drunk, and will develop a formal code of conduct for the astronaut corps, officials of the agency said Friday. With Congressional committees already promising hearings on alcohol use and other health issues, the officials said they had asked NASA's safety chief, Bryan D. O'Connor, to interview astronauts, flight surgeons and others to determine whether the agency had an alcohol problem.

results.abstract: Increasing amount of space junk forces NASA to alter flight plans to protect spacecraft; specific encounters with debris noted; drawing (M)

headline.main: NASA Forced to Steer Clear Of Junk in Cluttered Space

results.snippet: Recent satellite breakups and jettisoned trash pose hazards to spacecraft.
results.lead_paragraph: Traffic in space is getting so congested that flight controllers in the past few weeks have had to nudge three spacecraft out of harm's way, in one case to prevent the craft from colliding with its own trash. On July 23, controllers in Houston raised the orbit of the International Space Station by roughly five miles to avoid hitting a half-ton tank of ammonia that a spacewalking astronaut had tossed out earlier in the day while doing some housecleaning on the $100 billion outpost.
